page.title: 02LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: THE VILLAGE OF NORTH WHEATLEY TO THE EAST OF THE GRID WAS MENTIONED IN THE ORIGINAL DOMESDAY BOOK,THE NAME MEANING "WHEAT FIELDS".LAND AROUND THE VILLAGE WAS OWNED BY THE KING AND THE ARCHBISHOP OF YORK.LONG BEFORE THAT THE VILLAGE HAD BEEN ON THE ROUTE OF A ROMAN ROAD FROM LINCOLN TO DONCASTER, INDEED IT IS THOUGHT THAT THE REMAINS OF A VILLA ARE TO BE FOUND ON THE VILLAGE FIELD. THE SETTLEMENT ITSELF CONTAINS MANY OLD BUILDINGS. THERE WERE TWO CHURCHES,ONLY ONE OF WHICH SURVIVES, BOTH DATING FROM THE MIDDLE AGES.THEIR CONSTRUCTION WAS COMPLETED MUCH LATER HOWEVER. THERE ARE MANY EXAMPLES OF OLD PROPERTY WITHIN THE VILLAGE INCLUDING THE OLD HALL WHICH BEARS THE DATE 1673.
